notes:
1. Fundamental Properties

  • Density ($\rho$): Mass per unit volume (kg/m³). $\rho_{water} \approx 1000$ kg/m³.
  • Specific Weight ($\gamma$): Weight per unit volume (N/m³). $\gamma = \rho g$. $\gamma_{water} \approx 9810$ N/m³.
  • Specific Gravity (SG): Ratio of fluid density to density of water. Dimensionless. $SG = \rho / \rho_{water}$.

2. Viscosity

A measure of a fluid's resistance to deformation (flow).

  • Dynamic Viscosity ($\mu$): Ratio of shear stress to velocity gradient. Units: Pa·s or N·s/m².
  • Kinematic Viscosity ($\nu$): Ratio of dynamic viscosity to density. $\nu = \mu / \rho$. Units: m²/s.

3. Other Properties

  • Surface Tension ($\sigma$): Force per unit length at a liquid-gas interface. Causes capillarity.
  • Vapor Pressure ($P_v$): The pressure exerted by a vapor in thermodynamic equilibrium with its condensed phases. Cavitation occurs when liquid pressure drops below $P_v$.

solvedExamples.question: A fluid has a specific gravity of 0.8 and a dynamic viscosity of 0.01 Pa·s. What is its kinematic viscosity? ($\rho_{water} = 1000$ kg/m³)
solvedExamples.explanation: First, find the density: $\rho = SG \times \rho_{water} = 0.8 \times 1000 = 800$ kg/m³. Then, $\nu = \mu / \rho = 0.01 / 800 = 1.25 \times 10^{-5}$ m²/s.

solvedExamples.question: Cavitation in pumps is primarily caused by the fluid pressure dropping below its:
solvedExamples.explanation: When local static pressure drops below the fluid's vapor pressure, the liquid boils (flashes to vapor) forming bubbles. The subsequent collapse of these bubbles is cavitation.
